Executive Summary



2005 Update



Chemical storage and use at the Water Reclamation Plant remains the same and has not had any changes made to it since the last RMP submition in 1999.  The plant is currently in the process of a major expansion and upgrade.  The expansion will increase wastewater treatment capabilities by approximately 25%. The upgrade will replace the existing pumping station and preliminary treatment.  It will also expand the sludge thickening and storage capacities.  None of these changes or additions will alter the use or storage of chemicals.  As a part of the plant upgrade, a chlorine gas scrubber system will be installed to evacuate and neutralize any leaks which occur inside the storage building.  This would be considered a mechanical mitigation.  When the system is installed the WRP's RMP and PSM will be reviewed and updated.  Since chlorine cylinders will still off-loaded outside of the building the "worse case scenario" will remain unchanged.  



The Purpose of the Risk Management Plan



The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires facilities, which use potentially hazardous material, to assess the risks of any accidental release and develop a plan to minimize these risks.  These regulations are referred to as the Risk Management Plan and are found in section 112r of The Clean Air.  It is the intent of these regulations to reduce the number of offsite injuries and death that could occur from the accidental release of a hazardous substance.



What this Regulation Covers



The Rochester Water Reclamation Plant is the Publicly Owned Treatment Works (POTW) which treats the wastewater from the City of Rochester and its residents under the authority of the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES).  As a wastewater treatment plant the Rochester Water Reclamation Plant uses chemical that are common to the industry, including chlorine.  Chlorine is regulated under the risk management plan when used in quantities greater

than 2,500 pounds (maximum use in the process).  Chlorine is stored in one ton (2,000 pound cylinders).  



Chlorine



The Water Reclamation Plant is required by its NPDES permit to continuously disinfect its discharge from April through November of every year.  Chlorine has been used for many years as an economical safe, effective agent for disinfection.  To ensure that disinfection is not interrupted when changing chlorine cylinders, it is common in the wastewater industry to have multiple cylinders connected at one time.  Once a cylinder is exhausted the system automatically switches over to the back-up cylinders, thus ensuring an uninterrupted supply to meet the continuous disinfection.  Because more than one cylinder is hooked up at a time, the process is considered to have greater than 2,500 pounds of chlorine in it at one time.  Thus the Risk Management program rules apply.  



Other Alternatives



Although it is possible to obtain chlorine in smaller 150 pound cylinders, this size is impractical for use at the Water Reclamation Plant.  The use of 150 pound cylinder at the Water Reclamation Plant would exhaust more than one cylinder every day.  Although the use of these smaller cylinders would eliminate the need for complying with the Risk Management Plan it would create a greater hazard in the number of connections which have to be made.  Connecting and changing of cylinders is an operation that can potentially cause an accidental release.  Therefore, an appropriate sized cylinder is the safest all around alternative.  Chlorine is also available in larger rail car sized containers.






What is Not Regulated



Although the Water Reclamation Plant uses other chemicals, none of them are used in quantities above regulated threshold quantities.  The Water Regulation Plant does neutralize the chlorine discharge prior to mixing with the receiving stream, the South Fork of the Zumbro River.  Instead of using a regulated chemical such as sulfur dioxide, the Wa

ter Reclamation Plant uses a safer alternative, liquid sodium bisulfite.  



Flammable substances stored in quantities equal or greater than 10,000 pounds are also covered by the Risk Management Plan Regulations.  Although the Water Reclamation Plant does store methane ( a byproduct of wastewater solids digestion), it does not have the capacity store enough to be regulated (see figure 1).

Maximum Methane Storage Calculations



The Water Reclamation Plant does store digester gas in a 50-foot diameter high-pressure (Maximum 45-PSI) gas storage sphere.  

The following is a summary of the maximum storage calculations based on the formulas given in the Risk Management Program EPA Guidance Document for Wastewater Treatment Plants EPA 550-B-98-010:

Pm = (0.22) (0.7) / (460+1)    = 0.00334 pounds per Ft3



X = Percent of Gas    (50-70 Percent)

Quantity of Methane at Ambient Pressure (Qm)



Qm = V Pm

Qm = 65,417 Ft3 x 0.00334 pounds per Ft3 = 2185 Pounds

Qu = Qm x (Pm+Pa) / Pa

Qu 2185 Pounds ((45 PSI + 15PSI) / 15 PSI) = 8,740 Pounds



Pm = 45 PSI

Pa = 15 PSI 


Worst Case Scenario



Using the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance Document for Wastewater Treatment Plant's (EPA 550-B-98-010), the calculated distance to the toxic endpoint of an accidental release of chlorine is 1.3 miles in an urban setting.  This is a worst case scenario, which assumes the entire contents of a one ton cylinder escapes within a ten minute period of time.  This scenario assumes a worst case wind speed of 1.5 mile per hour, 25o C and a F stability.  The toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l (3ppm).



Alternative Scenario



Using the same guidance document the calculated distance to the toxic endpoint for and accidental r

elease of chlorine is 0.2 miles or 1056 feet.  This alternative scenario assumes a wind speed of 3 meters per second, 25o C and a D stability.  This alternative scenario is calculated based on a release the release of the entire content of a chlorine cylinder over a period of eighteen minutes.  This is less than the rate of release for the worst case scenario because it takes into account the mitigating effect of the chlorine cylinders being inside.  This alternative scenario represent an accidental release that is more to occur than that of the worst case scenario.



Offsite Receptors 



In the worst case scenario the 1.3 mile distance to endpoint would include a large residential area, several schools, public parks and business establishments.  The estimated population within that distance is 3,600 person using the Block Group Proportion Method.  This is the estimated population within the entire 1.3 mile radius around the facility.  Under either of the two scenarios the wind would limit the area impacted by a release to an actual area of less than 180o, , or half of the area of the entire circle.  In the case of an actual release it would be up to the emergency response to decide on the appropriate action to take.  This plan serves only as an aid in making informed decisions.

Program Level



Because the Water Reclamation Plant does have off-site receptors and is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation, it is subject to the level three program requirements of the Risk Management Plan.
